options.help:
Understanding Navigation

Navigation menus help visitors find their way around your site. You can create multiple menus (like main navigation, footer links, or utility menus) and manage them all from this collection.

Navigation Structure

Each navigation menu consists of:

  1. A menu container (Navigation)
  2. Menu items within it (Navigation Items)

Creating Navigation Menus

Menu Settings

Title

Internal name for your menu (only visible in admin). Examples:

  • "Main Navigation"
  • "Footer Links"
  • "Header Utility Menu"

Active Status

Toggle menus on/off without deleting them. Useful for:

  • Testing new menu structures
  • Seasonal navigation changes
  • Temporary menu updates

Adding Menu Items

Item Types

Page

  • Link to any page in your site
  • Automatically updates if page URL changes
  • Maintains internal link structure

Post

  • Link to a specific blog post
  • Useful for featuring important articles
  • Updates automatically if post URL changes

URL

  • Link to any external website (e.g., "https://example.com")
  • Create social media links
  • Link to specific file downloads
  • Add internal anchor links (e.g., "#contact-section")
  • Point to email addresses (e.g., "mailto:contact@example.com")
  • Link to phone numbers (e.g., "tel:+1234567890")

Group

  • Creates a container for other menu items
  • Appears as a dropdown menu when hovered
  • Can contain any mix of Pages, Posts, URLs, or other Groups
  • Perfect for organizing related content (e.g., "Services", "Products")
  • Can be nested to create multi-level navigation
  • Doesn't require a URL - acts as a category header

Examples of Group Usage:

About (Group) 
└─ Our Story (Page)
└─ Team (Page)
└─ Careers (URL - External job board)

Services (Group) 
└─ Consulting (Page) 
└─ Training (Group) 
└─ Online Courses (URL) 
└─ Workshops (Page) 
└─ Support (Page)

Item Settings

Title

The text shown to visitors in the menu

Parent Item

For creating nested navigation:

  • Select another item as parent
  • Creates dropdown menus
  • Builds hierarchical structure

Sort Order

Control the sequence of menu items:

  • Drag and drop to reorder
  • Items display in ascending order
  • Groups show as dropdowns

Best Practices

Structure

  • Keep main navigation simple
  • Limit dropdown levels to 2-3
  • Group related items logically
  • Use clear, concise labels

Usability

  • Ensure all items are reachable
  • Test on mobile devices
  • Review links regularly
  • Keep labels brief but descriptive
